verses.text: Give thanks to the LORD, call upon his name; make known his deeds among the peoples!
verses.comment: The psalm begins with a call to worship and proclaim God's mighty acts. The name 'LORD' (Yahweh) indicates the covenant relationship with Israel.

verses.text: Sing to him, sing praises to him; speak of all his wondrous works.
verses.comment: Worship is expressed through singing and recounting God's miracles, a practice continued in the Church's liturgy.

verses.text: Glory in his holy name; let the heart of those who seek the LORD rejoice.
verses.comment: 'His holy name' points to reverence for God, an aspect foundational in both Old and New Covenant worship.

verses.text: Seek the LORD and his strength; seek his presence continually.
verses.comment: The call to seek God continually indicates the ongoing need for relationship and dependence—not just in crisis.

verses.text: Remember the wondrous works that he has done, his miracles, and the judgments he has pronounced.
verses.comment: Remembrance of God's actions forms the core of biblical faith; this is echoed in later Christian practice and the command to 'do this in remembrance.'

verses.text: O offspring of Abraham his servant, children of Jacob, his chosen ones!
verses.comment: Identifying Israel as Abraham's children recalls the covenant promises and election, pointing toward their fulfillment in Christ (Gal. 3:29).

verses.text: He is the LORD our God; his judgments are in all the earth.
verses.comment: God's authority is universal, not limited to Israel—a theme Jesus affirms in extending the Kingdom to all nations.

verses.text: He remembers his covenant forever, the word that he commanded to a thousand generations,
verses.comment: God's faithfulness to his covenant extends to all generations; Christians view Jesus as the fulfillment of the everlasting covenant.

verses.text: the covenant that he made with Abraham, his sworn promise to Isaac,
verses.comment: References God's specific promises to the patriarchs, which are foundational in biblical history (see also Heb. 6:13–15).

verses.text: which he confirmed to Jacob as a statute, to Israel as an everlasting covenant,
verses.comment: The everlasting nature of the covenant underlines God's unchanging purpose, which the New Testament interprets as fulfilled in Christ (Luke 1:72–73).

verses.text: saying, 'To you I will give the land of Canaan as a portion for your inheritance.'
verses.comment: The earthly promise prefigures the spiritual inheritance of the faithful in the New Covenant.

verses.text: When they were few in number, of little account, and sojourners in it,
verses.comment: God's faithfulness is shown despite Israel's weakness; a pattern that recurs throughout salvation history.

verses.text: wandering from nation to nation, from one kingdom to another people,
verses.comment: The patriarchs' pilgrim status typifies the journey of God's people toward the true homeland (Heb. 11:13–16).

verses.text: he allowed no one to oppress them; he rebuked kings on their account,
verses.comment: God's protection over his anointed is a motif fulfilled ultimately in Christ (Matt. 2:12).

verses.text: saying, 'Touch not my anointed ones, do my prophets no harm!'
verses.comment: 'Anointed ones' refers not only to the patriarchs but anticipates Christ, the ultimate Anointed One (Acts 4:27).

verses.text: When he summoned a famine on the land and broke every staff of bread,
verses.comment: God's sovereignty includes judgment and provision, seen in the story of Joseph and the larger typology of suffering leading to salvation.

verses.text: he sent a man ahead of them, Joseph, who was sold as a servant.
verses.comment: Joseph prefigures Christ in suffering unjustly yet becoming the means of salvation for many (cf. Acts 7:9–14).

verses.text: They afflicted his feet with shackles; his neck was put in iron;
verses.comment: Joseph's suffering anticipates the suffering of the righteous servant in Isaiah and ultimately Christ.

verses.text: until what he had said came to pass, the word of the LORD tested him.
verses.comment: God's word is powerful and always fulfilled, though it tests the faithful (Ps. 12:6).

verses.text: The king sent and released him; the ruler of the peoples set him free;
verses.comment: God exalts the humble and brings them to prominence in his own time, as is fulfilled in Christ's resurrection and glorification.

verses.text: He made him lord of his house and ruler of all his possessions,
verses.comment: Joseph’s exaltation foreshadows Christ’s kingly role over God’s house, the Church (Heb. 3:6).

verses.text: to bind his princes at his pleasure and to teach his elders wisdom.
verses.comment: Wisdom and authority given to Joseph are a type of spiritual leadership which finds its fullness in God's ultimate Shepherd.

verses.text: Then Israel came to Egypt; Jacob sojourned in the land of Ham.
verses.comment: 'Land of Ham' refers poetically to Egypt; Israel's descent into Egypt sets the stage for the Exodus.

verses.text: And the LORD made his people very fruitful and made them stronger than their foes.
verses.comment: God's blessing fulfills the creation mandate to be fruitful, further demonstrating his faithfulness.

verses.text: He turned their hearts to hate his people, to deal craftily with his servants.
verses.comment: God’s providence includes even adversity; he works through all circumstances to reveal his glory.

verses.text: He sent Moses his servant, and Aaron, whom he had chosen.
verses.comment: Moses and Aaron are models of divinely appointed leadership, a theme developed further with apostolic succession in the New Testament (Acts 6:6).

verses.text: They performed his signs among them and miracles in the land of Ham.
verses.comment: The miracles in Egypt stand as manifestations of God's direct intervention—to save and judge.

verses.text: He sent darkness and made the land dark; they did not rebel against his words.
verses.comment: This refers to the ninth plague. The ‘they’ likely refers to Moses and Aaron, who obeyed God’s command.

verses.text: He turned their waters into blood and caused their fish to die.
verses.comment: The first plague shows God's power over creation and his authority to judge.

verses.text: Their land swarmed with frogs, even in the chambers of their kings.
verses.comment: Relates to the second plague. Even royalty was not spared from God’s judgments.

verses.text: He spoke, and there came swarms of flies and gnats throughout their country.
verses.comment: God's spoken word brings about creation and judgment (Gen. 1; John 1:1-3).

verses.text: He gave them hail for rain, and flaming fire in their land.
verses.comment: The seventh plague—hail mingled with fire—demonstrates God’s control over the elements.

verses.text: He struck down their vines and fig trees and shattered the trees of their land.
verses.comment: Total devastation was brought on Egypt, signifying God’s overwhelming power to save his people.

verses.text: He spoke, and the locusts came—young locusts without number,
verses.comment: The eighth plague was locusts, consuming all that was left, signifying total judgment.

verses.text: which devoured all the vegetation in their land and ate the fruit of their ground.
verses.comment: A literal account; also symbolically points to the severity of judgment without repentance.

verses.text: He struck down every firstborn in their land, the firstfruits of all their strength.
verses.comment: The Passover and Exodus foreshadow the redemption found in Christ, the true Firstborn (Col. 1:15-20).

verses.text: Then he brought Israel out with silver and gold, and there was none among his tribes who stumbled.
verses.comment: The Exodus was a total deliverance, accompanied by material blessing; later seen as spiritual freedom in Christ.

verses.text: Egypt was glad when they departed, for dread of them had fallen upon it.
verses.comment: God’s mighty works bring fear to his enemies and joy to his people.

verses.text: He spread a cloud for a covering, and fire to give light by night.
verses.comment: God’s guidance in the wilderness is a sign of his continual presence; this prefigures the guidance given to the Church through the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: They asked, and he brought quail, and satisfied them with the bread of heaven.
verses.comment: Manna is the 'bread of heaven,' prefiguring the true bread, Christ’s body given to believers (John 6:32-51).

verses.text: He opened the rock, and water flowed out; it ran in the dry places like a river.
verses.comment: Paul identifies the rock with Christ, highlighting the spiritual sustenance God provides (1 Cor. 10:4).

verses.text: For he remembered his holy promise, and Abraham his servant.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness is linked to his promises, ultimately culminating in Jesus, the promised descendant.

verses.text: So he brought out his people with joy, his chosen ones with singing.
verses.comment: The joyful deliverance recalls Miriam’s song at the Red Sea, prefiguring the new song of salvation.

verses.text: He gave them the lands of the nations, and they inherited what the peoples had toiled for,
verses.comment: Israel’s inheritance prefigures the final reward for God’s people—an image of the heavenly inheritance (Heb. 4:8-11).

verses.text: that they might keep his statutes and observe his laws. Praise the LORD!
verses.comment: Obedience to God’s law is the correct response to God’s gracious deliverance. Jesus commands his disciples likewise to keep all he has taught.
